title: (x) Cover of the first edition of Peter S. Beagle's "The Last Unicorn" - Kismet (Spiral) {Arun (Stephen)}
content:
There is a typeface used for the first edition of Beagle’s _The Last Unicorn_ that I absolutely adore. I actually came across its name by pure luck while browsing a book on graphic design, but have since forgotten its name. Can anyone help?

Example: [http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6f/Last\_unicorn\_hb.jpg/...](http://web.archive.org/web/20080410224115/http:/upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6f/Last_unicorn_hb.jpg/200px-Last_unicorn_hb.jpg "http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6f/Last\_unicorn\_hb.jpg/200px-Last\_unicorn\_hb.jpg")

 [‹ Looking for a squared, but also a little bit rounded free font](http://web.archive.org/web/20080410224115/http:/www.typophile.com/node/39911 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Who created Alphabet 26? - Bradbury Thompson {Dan Reynolds} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080410224115/http:/www.typophile.com/node/39888 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Clay

comments.content: A slightly different version was digitized by Richard Beatty as [Spiral](http://web.archive.org/web/20080410224115/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=Spiral). It’s available with two sets of caps.

Believe it or not, in the middle of the night I suddenly remembered “Kismet!” I felt rather dumb for wasting people’s time with the post. But Spiral is new to me, and, at first blush, seems to be more complete than Kismet, what with slashes and other punctuation fully integrated into the design. Very interesting, thanks!
